summary.long: Jonah is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: Now this message from the Lord came to Amittai’s son Jonah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up and go to Nineveh, that great city! Then cry out in protest against it, because their evil has come to my attention.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jonah got up and fled from the Lord to Tarshish. He went down to Joppa, secured passage on a ship bound for Tarshish, paid the fare, and boarded, intending to go with the mariners to Tarshish to escape from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord sent a great wind over the sea, and a severe storm broke out. It seemed as if the ship were about to break up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this point the mariners became terrified, and each man cried out to his gods. They began to throw the cargo into the sea in order to lighten the vessel. But Jonah had gone down into the vessel’s hold, had lain down, and was fast asleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the captain approached him, and told him, “What are you doing asleep? Get up! Call on your gods! Maybe your god will think about us so we won’t die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, each crewman told another, “Come on! Let’s cast lots to find out whose fault it is that we’re in this trouble.” So they cast lots, and the lot indicated Jonah!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they interrogated him: “Tell us, why has this trouble come upon us? What’s your occupation? Where’d you come from? What’s your home country? What’s your nationality?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m a Hebrew,” he replied, “and I’m afraid of the Lord God of heaven, who made the sea—along with the dry land!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In mounting terror, the men asked him, “What have you done?” The men were aware that he was fleeing from the Lord, because he had admitted this to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the sea was growing more and more stormy, they asked him, “What do we have to do to you so the sea will calm down for us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonah told them, “Pick me up and toss me into the sea. Then the sea will calm down for you, because I know that it’s my fault that this mighty storm has come upon you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even so, the crewmen rowed hard to bring the ship toward dry land, but they were unsuccessful, because the sea was growing more and more stormy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At last they cried out to the Lord, “Please, Lord, do not let us perish because of this man’s life, and do not hold us responsible for innocent blood, because you, Lord, have done what pleased you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they picked up Jonah and tossed him into the sea, and the sea stopped raging.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men feared the Lord greatly, offered a sacrifice to the Lord, and made vows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord had prepared a large sea creature to swallow Jonah, and Jonah was inside the sea creature for three days and three nights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonah prayed to the Lord his God from inside the sea creature.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said:
“I called out to the Lord from the midst of affliction directed at me,
    and he answered me.
From the depths of death I cried out for help;
    and you heard my cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You cast me into the deep—
    into the heart of the sea.
Flood waters engulfed me.
    All your breakers and your waves swirled over me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I told myself, ‘I have been driven away from you.
    How will I again gaze on your holy Temple?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flood waters encompassed me,
    the deep surrounded me
        while seaweed wrapped around my head.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Those who cling to vain idols
    leave behind the gracious love that could have been theirs.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke to the sea creature, and it spewed Jonah onto the dry land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jonah a second time:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up and go to Nineveh, that great city, and proclaim to it the message that I tell you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Jonah got up and went to Nineveh to do what the Lord had ordered.
Now Nineveh was a very large city, requiring a three-day journey to cross through it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Jonah started into the city on the first day’s journey, he proclaimed the message, “40 days more and Nineveh will be overthrown!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Nineveh believed God. They called for a fast and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them to the least important.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the message reached the king of Nineveh, he got up from his throne, removed his royal garments, covered himself with sackcloth, and sat down in ashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he had this proclamation published throughout Nineveh:
“By decree of the king and his nobles: 
No man or animal, herd or flock, is to taste anything, graze, or drink water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, let both man and animal clothe themselves with sackcloth and cry out to God forcefully. Let every person turn from his evil ways and from his tendency to do violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who knows but that God may relent, have compassion, and turn from his fierce anger, so that we are not exterminated?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God took note of what they did—that they turned from their evil ways. Because God relented concerning the trouble about which he had warned them, he did not carry it out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greatly displeased, Jonah flew into a rage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he prayed to the Lord, “Lord, isn’t this what I said while I was still in my home country? That’s why I fled previously to Tarshish, because I knew you’re a compassionate God, slow to anger, overflowing with gracious love, and reluctant to send trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, Lord, please kill me, because it’s better for me to die than to live!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord replied, “Does being angry make you right?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonah left the city and sat down on the eastern side. There he made a shelter for himself and sat down under its shade to see what would happen to the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God prepared a vine plant, and it grew over Jonah to shade his head and provide relief from his misery. Jonah was happy—indeed, he was ecstatic—about the vine plant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But at dawn the next day, God provided a worm that attacked the vine plant so that it withered away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sun rose, God prepared a harsh east wind. The sun beat down on Jonah’s head, he became faint, and he begged to die. “It is better for me to die than to live!” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then God asked Jonah, “Is your anger about the vine plant justified?”
And he answered, “Absolutely! I’m so angry I could die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord asked, “You cared about a vine plant that you neither worked on nor cultivated? A vine plant that grew up overnight and died overnight?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So why shouldn’t I be concerned about Nineveh, that great city, in which there are more than 120,000 human beings who do not know their right hand from their left, as well as a lot of livestock?
verses.speaker: Narrator
